Thanks

406-482-3243 evenings I do tsukamaki (wrapping of sword hilts)

messages.subject: Re: photos added to album
messages.msgSnippet: Barry, I have been away dealing with family tragedy. Having returned to a Nihonto state of mind, were you able to find that other character for the lousy
messages.messageBody:
Barry,

I have been away dealing with 'family' tragedy. Having returned to
a 'Nihonto' state of mind, were you able to find that other character
for the lousy mei of Mune-? Tom gave me a lead that I have studied.

I am continuing my pursuit of possibly figuring out this signature.

Thanks for Tom's and your effort,

Elliott

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@...>
wrote:
>
> Tom,
>
> It's a pretty lousy MUNE- I have another character in mind but
haven't looked for it yet. It is well-known that most signatures on
kogatana are spurious, and IMHO these are no exception. Elliot, I am
sorry but it pains me to say that the characters are crudely
chiselled with no finesse whatsoever. A cursory run through my
kogatana book does not reveal any examples signed in such a
rudimentary manner. I have found a Tadahiro but it is nothing like
the piece under consideration. I doubt there is much to learn from
these pieces. It always pays to bear in mind one of Albert
Yamanaka's immortal sayings "Looking at bad swords ruins your eye".
It is no less true for kogatana... But as Tom says, thanks for
posting Elliot. As a counter to Albert's advice, one of my truisms
has always been "Look at everything"...
>
> Regards,
> Barry Thomas.
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Tom Helm
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Wednesday, March 28, 2007 3:56 PM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] photos added to album
>
>
> Elliott -
> looks like quite a bit of the mei is missing but I would look at
> Hitachi no Kami Muneshige of Settsu. Based on your photos that is
my
> best guess. I am also curious about the temper you mentioned, is
it
> only on the reverse? Can you show photos of the hamon for each of
> these? might help confirm what the signature says...
> -t
> and thanks for posting.
>
> On Mar 27, 2007, at 7:03 PM, Elliott wrote:
>
> > Please go to second page of my album. I have two pictures of
each; the
> > one in question and the Tadahiro kogatana.
> >
> > I am open to all comments, especially if you can decipher the
one I
> > can't find. All I can hope for is that I purchased something
that is
> > old and I can learn from.
> >
> > Thanks for your help, you guys are great.
> >
> > Elliott
> .
>
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
>

messages.subject: Re: photos added to album
messages.msgSnippet: Thank you guys, I like your truism of look at everything . How else are you going to learn. Of course, you must look at bad and good. Then you understand the
messages.messageBody:
Thank you guys,

I like your truism of 'look at everything'. How else are you going
to learn. Of course, you must look at bad and good. Then you
understand the difference.

I should not have brought up the temper - it's a lousy job of a fake
temper. Whoever applied the fake temper should be shot! I refuse to
leave it alone, I must have it removed. You can see the scratches
left by what-ever tool the idiot used. Yes. it's only on the side
opposite the (?)mei.

Thanks, let me know about the other character.

Elliott

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] photos added to album
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, It s a pretty lousy MUNE-  I have another character in mind but haven t looked for it yet.  It is well-known that most signatures on kogatana are
messages.messageBody:
Tom,

It's a pretty lousy MUNE- I have another character in mind but haven't looked for it yet. It is well-known that most signatures on kogatana are spurious, and IMHO these are no exception. Elliot, I am sorry but it pains me to say that the characters are crudely chiselled with no finesse whatsoever. A cursory run through my kogatana book does not reveal any examples signed in such a rudimentary manner. I have found a Tadahiro but it is nothing like the piece under consideration. I doubt there is much to learn from these pieces. It always pays to bear in mind one of Albert Yamanaka's immortal sayings "Looking at bad swords ruins your eye". It is no less true for kogatana... But as Tom says, thanks for posting Elliot. As a counter to Albert's advice, one of my truisms has always been "Look at everything"...

Regards,
Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Tom Helm
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, March 28, 2007 3:56 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] photos added to album


Elliott -
looks like quite a bit of the mei is missing but I would look at
Hitachi no Kami Muneshige of Settsu. Based on your photos that is my
best guess. I am also curious about the temper you mentioned, is it
only on the reverse? Can you show photos of the hamon for each of
these? might help confirm what the signature says...
-t
and thanks for posting.

On Mar 27, 2007, at 7:03 PM, Elliott wrote:

> Please go to second page of my album. I have two pictures of each; the
> one in question and the Tadahiro kogatana.
>
> I am open to all comments, especially if you can decipher the one I
> can't find. All I can hope for is that I purchased something that is
> old and I can learn from.
>
> Thanks for your help, you guys are great.
>
> Elliott
.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] photos added to album
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, It s a pretty lousy MUNE-  I have another character in mind but haven t looked for it yet.  It is well-known that most signatures on kogatana are
messages.messageBody:
Tom,

It's a pretty lousy MUNE- I have another character in mind but haven't looked for it yet. It is well-known that most signatures on kogatana are spurious, and IMHO these are no exception. Elliot, I am sorry but it pains me to say that the characters are crudely chiselled with no finesse whatsoever. A cursory run through my kogatana book does not reveal any examples signed in such a rudimentary manner. I have found a Tadahiro but it is nothing like the piece under consideration. I doubt there is much to learn from these pieces. It always pays to bear in mind one of Albert Yamanaka's immortal sayings "Looking at bad swords ruins your eye". It is no less true for kogatana... But as Tom says, thanks for posting Elliot. As a counter to Albert's advice, one of my truisms has always been "Look at everything"...

Regards,
Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: Tom Helm
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, March 28, 2007 3:56 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] photos added to album


Elliott -
looks like quite a bit of the mei is missing but I would look at
Hitachi no Kami Muneshige of Settsu. Based on your photos that is my
best guess. I am also curious about the temper you mentioned, is it
only on the reverse? Can you show photos of the hamon for each of
these? might help confirm what the signature says...
-t
and thanks for posting.

On Mar 27, 2007, at 7:03 PM, Elliott wrote:

> Please go to second page of my album. I have two pictures of each; the
> one in question and the Tadahiro kogatana.
>
> I am open to all comments, especially if you can decipher the one I
> can't find. All I can hope for is that I purchased something that is
> old and I can learn from.
>
> Thanks for your help, you guys are great.
>
> Elliott
.

messages.subject: photos added to album
messages.msgSnippet: Please go to second page of my album. I have two pictures of each; the one in question and the Tadahiro kogatana. I am open to all comments, especially if you
messages.messageBody:
Please go to second page of my album. I have two pictures of each; the
one in question and the Tadahiro kogatana.

I am open to all comments, especially if you can decipher the one I
can't find. All I can hope for is that I purchased something that is
old and I can learn from.

Thanks for your help, you guys are great.

Elliott
